That is a general observation with which I concur. It is interesting to see how supportive the industry is at the moment about that element of the car plan. Only in the last few days I received a copy of the report of the President of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries which was presented to the annual general meeting on Monday, 15 April-less than a month ago. There are a couple of passages which go to the point made by Senator Button when he introduced the car plan. Those statements amount to very substantial support for the proposition the Minister advanced that the plan should be not negotiable. In reference to the passenger car plan, on the first page of that report the President said:

Whilst across the industry there are differing views on the contents of the new plan, in general, all sectors of the industry would agree that it does provide a basic framework to develop long term strategies for the future.
He went on to say:
It is imperative that the plans now in shape remain unchanged in the run up to 1992 by Governments of whatever political persuasion.

If I may interpolate this little message for the Opposition in that particular passage, they are suggesting that, even given a change of government, it is important that there should be stability and that the plan which has been put forward should remain unchanged. The next paragraph is also important, not in the context of the argument for stability but rather in reminding us that the benign view of the car plan that is abroad in 1985 is a view that needs to be measured in light of the general circumstances in which the industry is presently operating. The report goes on to point out that 1984 was a record year for new motor vehicle sales, and I will refer to that matter a little later. At page 9 of the report the President further stated:
No matter what our differences--
that is the differences within the industry--
we must seek assurance from governments and oppositions that their policies have stability and long term duration

Again, I simply acknowledge the importance of the point being made by the industry that, if there is to be a basis for investment, there does need to be predictability and stability. If the rules are to be changed in the middle of the game obviously one can invalidate investment decisions already made. It has always seemed to me that there is a rank element of injustice, quite apart from anything else, in that readiness to change the rules when they have been laid down clearly.

As far as this piece of legislation is concerned, the Opposition made an early commitment to support it. I refer the Senate to the Policy on Industry and Commerce issued by the then shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Peter Rae, well prior to the election last year. At page 9 of that policy it specifically provided in a sub-paragraph, under the heading 'Industry and Taxation':

provide increased research and development incentives including the retention of that currently promised to the Automobile industry which will be particularly directed towards sections of the component parts industry;

There was an early commitment of support by the Opposition for this particular element of the car plan, and that was in line with the broad support offered by the Opposition to the plan at the time it was brought down.

We are dealing with an industry which is going through what has been described as a boom year. I have an extract from the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 30 April, which is headlined 'Car Sales Take Off in March' and which refers to March being the best month in the history of the Australian car industry, with registrations at 65,160, almost 10,000 more than February. I will not quote the article at length as I am sure the Minister is very familiar with the figures. The article goes on to say that there has been a significant upgrading of the estimates of vehicle sales for the current year. Quite apart from the good year in 1984, dealt with in the Chamber of Automotive Industries' report to which I have referred, we have the prospect of an extremely good year in 1985.

Given the views the industry is putting forward in these rather halcyon days, I make the observation that it might be quite important for the industry to consider its advice to governments and to oppositions and to be prepared perhaps to give the same assurance to politicians as it is seeking from politicians. I do not think there is any doubt in anybody's mind that the plan that has been put forward is one that envisages substantial restructuring of the industry. That process of restructuring is not one which is ever without difficulty. When in a few years the pips start to squeak we might find that the industry will need to remember some of the advice which is currently being proffered to the Minister and to the Opposition.

I say that because although a good deal has been made of the fact that this plan is predicated on there being a tougher competitive situation, the reality is that the plan is not all that tough in 1985. The tough years are yet to come. I think that is evident from the perusal of the plan and from the fact that when the plan was brought down last year some elements of it effectively involved some temporary further assistance to the industry. For example, the short term measures which were announced at that time included changes to the way certain passenger cars, which are currently classified as light commercial four-wheel drive vehicles and which therefore attract a lower rate of duty were dealt with. Those vehicles were brought under the passenger motor vehicle plan and attracted the same rate of duty as that which applied to passenger motor vehicles generally.

It is important to note that we are at a stage where there has been a very substantial lift in sales, where there have been some short term changes which are quite beneficial to the industry in the short term and where the reductions in duty, which are a very significant feature of the plan and, in my view, a very appropriate feature of the plan, have yet really to make life difficult. The fact is that from the industry's point of view the tough times are not now. The $150m which is to be distributed under the provisions of the legislation before us now is effectively a sweetener to the car industry plan which is really being proffered at a time of record sales and continuing high protection.

The 100 per cent penalty tariff which is part of this plan, which is less than the penalty tariff which had applied and which phases down on an annual basis to 57 1/2 per cent, does constitute a high level of protection now. We face the prospect of a very significant diminution in that level of protection. Of course, that means that the position of the Australian industry will become more open to competition. One can look at that in two different ways. One can say that the maintenance of a 57 1/2 per cent tariff as late as 1992 would still represent a very high level of protection for the industry. Certainly in terms of the general protection afforded to manufacturing industry it is high. But I would freely concede that that is significantly better in terms of there being more open access than the levels of penalty tariff which were in the car plan which this plan replaced and in which there would still have been a significantly higher rate of penalty tariff in 1991.

I would be interested if the Minister in his response to the second reading debate could indicate to us whether he sees those fundamental arrangements which he laid down last year as being under any threat from the developments which are proceeding in the car industry. It seems to me that one of the realities that Australian car manufacturers face is that they are not simply in the business of improving themselves to some fixed standard. The reality is that the competition is improving and the target they are pursuing is not a fixed target, but a moving target. No doubt the Minister has been considering the questions which arise over the entry of, for example, Korea into the field and the potential Korea has for very low cost production and for putting extremely competitive products on the market in a way which, as at least one writer I have seen has suggested, invalidates some of the fundamental assumptions of the car plan. I think that needs to be considered. The Minister has said that the plan is not negotiable. It will be interesting to see whether he sees any threat to that position in the emergence of possible competition from Korea at a level which might put the figuring which underlies the plan in some doubt.

I do not wish to deal at any great length with the position provided for by this Bill. The Bill generally is designed to rectify the low level of research and development which has occurred in Australia. The Minister made some comments about that in a broader sense in Question Time today. This Bill invests the Automotive Industry Authority, which was established last year, with the power to select projects for assistance, to determine the amount of assistance-although there are some guidelines with respect to the proportion of assistance which is to be provided-and to make decisions with respect to the duration of that assistance. In addition, there are provisions that grant payment is to be made by way of formal agreement, that limitations on funding are to be subject to ministerial discretion, that penalties can be imposed and moneys recovered, that ministerial direction can be provided for public interest projects and so on.

Aspects of this legislation do cause me some concern and I will raise them in more particular terms now. I also ask the Minister to give some indication of the extent to which he sees in the operation of the car plan a little further down the track the need for the Government to take a more directive approach than that which was adopted in the original laying out of the plan. I raise that because I think I need to stress that there could be some limits to the extent to which the Opposition would continue to support the plan if it came to the point where manufacturers in Australia formed their own judgment that they could compete within the tariff parameters which have been established by the Government and yet the Government was determined to drive out manufacturers purely to conform with the numerical elements of the plan which were laid down by the Minister last year.

In other words, whilst the Opposition can see the value of opening the industry to a more competitive environment, the Opposition can also see the value of the industry, in that more competitive environment, looking to the rationalisation of its production and the Opposition can see virtue in the industry deciding to produce fewer models and generally behaving in a way which would make the Australian industry more competitive. It seems that, with the extent to which the present Government is prepared to act in a directive way, if the market forces to which it is exposing the industry do not achieve the results which it seeks, it would be helpful to us to know just how far the Government is prepared to go in that direction. It may be, of course, that the Government simply wishes to hold its views in its hand on all that until facts become clearer. I think it would be worth canvassing some of those issues in the interests of ensuring that as far as possible there is some common understanding of the way this plan should proceed in the interests of the stability which the Minister and the industry seek.

Before I foreshadow the specific amendments I wish to move in Committee, I raise with the Minister the general concern I had when I looked at the provisions of the Bill with respect to the very considerable powers which it seems to me are vested in the Authority in respect of, for example, the registration of new entrants into the field. It seems to me that the Bill clearly provides a place for those who are actually involved in the production of the requisite components and so on now, but there is room within the Bill for new manufacturers to enter the industry. Fairly broad powers seem to be vested in the Authority with respect to the admission or non-admission of new companies to the arrangements which are provided in the provisions of this Bill. I must say that the Opposition gave consideration to whether we should provide some sort of appeal mechanism to cover the rights of any manufacturer who thought he was being wrongly excluded from the potential benefits of the Bill.

The Opposition determined, after consideration of the eighth annual report of the Administrative Review Council and the explanation of that Council, what sort of decisions are not appropriate for review, and it particularly defined issues of protection policy it thought involved high government policy as issues which should not be made subject to judicial review. For that reason I shall not be seeking an amendment, but I would like some assurance at least from the Minister that any decisions by the Authority to exclude future entrants into manufacturing in these areas would be a matter which would at least be considered at a parliamentary level, and that we would get some understanding that there would not be an attempt to use the Authority to prevent new and potentially good entrepreneurs from getting into this important industrial field.

I go on to the areas where the Opposition has concerns that will give rise to some amendments. The Bill is interesting in that it provides a broad general framework and then allows for a good deal of more detailed provision to be made by way of ministerial guidelines. It is proposed in proposed new section 26M that these guidelines should have a major influence, in my view, on the shape of this legislation and the operations of this Authority. I do not have the Act before me and I shall refer to it in Committee, but the point I wish to make at the second reading stage is that the guidelines given to the Minister would effectively enable substantial parts of the Act to be rewritten. It would be my view that the Minister could, by the issuing of guidelines, for example, limit the availability of grants to, say, component manufacturers or, alternatively, to car manufacturers.

The extent to which the Minister could change the shape of this legislation by the use of guidelines seems to me considerable. For that reason it will be the Opposition's intention to move to make the guidelines subject to a disallowance by the Parliament. I stress that in moving that amendment the Opposition would not be seeking in any way to disrupt the administration of the Authority, because we do not think that would be helpful at this stage. The Opposition has not taken the view that the temporary or initial guidelines put down by the Minister are inappropriate, but we understand that further guidelines are to be produced by him. Whilst these guidelines will be published, I would point out that they are beyond the reach of parliament. We think that is unfortunate and we would seek amendments to bring them within the reach of parliament. In that respect we simply say that the calling of what are effectively regulations guidelines should not in our view remove the issues from parliamentary scrutiny.

The other matter I wish to deal with is what is to be done with public interest projects where the Government, under the provisions of the legislation, arranges for research to be conducted by the Government itself through some agent. We propose to move amendments which would simply require the results of that research to be made available to Australian manufacturers after some process of tender. I understand that the Government is sympathetic to that approach being adopted.

I regard this, like any other aspect of the car industry plan, as a matter of great significance for Australia. I have tried to explain why the Opposition supports the legislation. We see force in the general direction of the car plan and the general move which it provides to expose the Australian industry to a more competitive environment. We note that even by 1992 the extent of that competitive environment is still to provide the Australian industry with protection at the level of a 57 1/2 per cent tariff. We see that as a target which the Australian industry should be prepared to accept as it appears to accept during the halcyon days of 1985. I express the hope that there will be the same determination as is evident in 1985 in later years when perhaps car sales are not necessarily as high and when the lower tariff protection is applicable.

talk.start.para: —It depends on the Government's view of the general economic situation.

—I am sure that if we are in government there will be many fewer problems, but I am trying to deal with this matter in a reasonably bipartisan way. We can have a stoush in the Committee stage later perhaps, if Senator Button would like that. I acknowledge the evident enthusiasm and energy which is being shown by the plan manufacturers. I have not yet had a chance to visit all of them, but it appears to me that they regard the plan as a challenge they are able to meet. That is encouraging for Australia and I certainly hope that the optimism that is currently being expressed by those of them I have talked with is transferred into results. I think anything else I want to say on this Bill can be said in Committee. I commend the broad direction of the car plan. I hope that it will be successful and I also hope that it will not involve the undue direction of the industry by government by administrative or other fait. I seek some assurance from the Minister on that and the other points I have raised.

speech.speaker: Foreman Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: -I speak in support of the Automotive Industry Authority Amendment Bill 1985. This Bill contains amendments to the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984, which will provide for financial assistance to projects concerned with the development of motor vehicles and components of Australian design. I am pleased to be able to support this Bill, which is another step in the Government's program to revitalise the motor industry. The motor vehicle building industry is one of the most important manufacturing industries in Australia. It is the largest component of our nation's engineering sector, employing some 6.8 per cent of all employees in the total manufacturing trade. Throughout Australia some 71,704 people are employed directly in the industry, and many more jobs than this are generated in a wide range of associated industries such as rubber, plastics, paint and glass.

speech.para: In my home State of South Australia nearly 15,000 people are directly involved in motor vehicle assembly and component manufacture. This represents some 15.6 per cent of South Australia's work force. So in South Australia and in Australia as a whole the motor vehicle industry is an important part of the nation's industrial composition. Unfortunately, over the last 20 years the motor vehicle industry in Australia has declined in both efficiency and output. It has become very highly protected, while at the same time its performance has become increasingly less satisfactory. Our export trade has decreased, our vehicle manufactures have proliferated, as has the number of model lines they produce and, because of a lack of rationalisation, component manufacturers are either producing small numbers of a wide range of items or competing with each other for a share of the market. Australian car manufacturers have been reluctant to make changes. Rather than embark on research and development programs, they have tended to bury their heads in the sand and rely on government protection.

What Australia had was a badly organised motor industry which had suffered from piecemeal attempts to bolster it up over the years, so that it has become no longer a viable industry but has needed massive financial protection from the Government in order to survive. The establishment of the Automotive Industry Authority late last year set in motion a long term plan to put the industry back on its feet, to make it more responsible for itself, to give it more status and to make it economically more viable. The motor industry itself had recognised the need for some sort of central authority to help it out of the quagmire it had slipped into, and so the Car Industry Council, composed of representatives from all sectors of the motor industry, approached the Government with the request that it set up such a body. Thus the Automotive Industry Authority came into being to assist the motor industry to build on its strengths, emphasise its positive aspects and streamline its operations.

The Bill before us now seeks to put into operation one of the fundamental objectives of the Government's motor vehicle industry policy-to place the industry in a better competitive position against imports. Its purpose is to encourage the development of an identifiably Australian design in the motor vehicle. As a person who has been involved in the vehicle building industry, both as an employee and as a union representative, I am keenly aware of the importance to Australia of a viable and self-generating motor industry. I would be happy to see the proposals contained in this Bill come to fruition.

If we continue to export from this country cars which have been designed overseas and so are recognised as the product of another country, how can we hope to establish a demand for a purely Australian motor vehicle? How can we hope to compete seriously and effectively on the overseas market? We need to feel proud of the vehicles which we produce in this country. From a purely national point of view, Australians will identify with Australian-designed products. There has been a great and long overdue surge in national pride in the last few years, culminating in the elation every Australian felt when Australia II captured the America's Cup. Our country has at last come of age, and takes a rightful pride in exporting its own product, whether that product be human or material. Australia no longer regards itself as a poor relation of Europe and America, and Australians would be happy to identify with locally designed and manufactured motor vehicles as in the past they used to identify with the Holden. We need to see Australian cars achieve the same world fame and reputation as, say, the German Volkswagen or the English Morris.

From the point of view of the Australian economy, excellent and stylish Australian designs will enable the Australian motor vehicle manufacturers to compete successfully on world markets. New markets can be created, competition can be met and challenged, and there is the possibility that Australian-designed cars could become leaders in years to come. We must remember that during the 1960s a significant volume of Australian cars were exported overseas. General Motors-Holden's Ltd, for example, exported over 30 per cent of its product. We were a major vehicle exporting country. But since then we have fallen into the sorry state of what Senator Button terms an 'industrial colony'. However, it is always possible for us to again build up our export trade to equal, if not exceed, that of the 1960s. An increase in exports, together with the proposed reduction in the number of models, but longer production runs, are logical measures to increase the cost competitiveness of the industry. The export of built-up vehicles would employ the whole range of skill in the Australian automotive industry, and establish an international reputation for Australia's excellence in these skills. There is no reason why Australia should not aim for such goals as product quality and international reputation. Our workers are as skilled as any in the world, and we should not let ourselves be discouraged by the size of our population. The recent intensive advertising campaign by the Swedish Volvo company was aimed at illustrating the very point of a country with a small domestic market being able to establish a glowing international reputation by producing a car which has become a by-word for excellence.

As in recent years the decline of the motor industry has unfortunately been responsible for bringing about an increase in unemployment, it is good to see the new Automotive Industry Authority being established, under whose guidance the industry can gain new strengths and hopefully provide new opportunities for employment. At last we can see the possibility of the automotive industry becoming competitive and efficient, so that the strength of Australia's manufacturing industry can be maintained. It is with much pleasure that I commend this Bill to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

talk.start.para: -Tonight the Senate is debating the Automotive Industry Authority Amendment Bill which seeks to incorporate into the original 1984 legislation a new Part IVA which will deal with the research grants payable in the motor vehicle industry as an integral part of the Government's overall automobile industry package. I think it is fair to look at the package as it was originally put down in May 1984 and to draw attention to circumstances and developments which have occurred since that date and which call into question not so much the plan itself but whether the plan needs any fine tuning and how the Government is going to respond to some of the developments which have taken place in the industry since the original package was announced.

speech.para: Senator Chaney has addressed a couple of remarks to this issue already, but I want to make a few additional observations. In its report of 24 June 1981 entitled 'Passenger Motor Vehicles and Components-Post-1984 Assistance Arrangements' the Industries Assistance Commission said:

Of course, a basic thrust of the Commission's approach is that some existing producers must cease operations. Indeed, it sees withdrawal of some producers and higher scales of operation by those remaining as the only sure way of achieving significant improvements in the international competitiveness of the automotive manufacturing industry.

The IAC's attitude was reflected in statements made subsequently by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. In addressing the Trade Union Training Authority Vehicle Industry Seminar on 18 July 1984 Senator Button among his remarks-to which I will be returning later-said:
We have made it clear that we will be seeking to consolidate the industry into two or three manufacturing groups.

There is no doubt that rationalisation of the industry along the lines that the IAC and Senator Button were talking about is a major long term goal of the plan which the Government has put into effect, and undoubtedly has been a factor in the stand taken by the Opposition, expressed by Senator Chaney this evening, in overall support of what the Government is seeking to do.

But there are some difficulties on the horizon and I think one of these is the potential entry into the market of manufactured vehicles from Korea. The plan which has associated with Alan Bond and Bond Motor Sales Pty Ltd in its agreement with the Hyundai Motor Corporation of Korea, I think, is a warning sign that the comfortable, cosy in-house arrangements which appear to have developed as a result of the motor vehicle industry package agreed among existing operators and the Government's response to it are not necessarily going to be able to persist as a central element of that plan. I do not want to go into the detail of the entry of Hyundai into the market through the Bond operation into Australia, but I simply say this. The sort of economic impact that those Korean vehicles could have has been indicated by one of the significant motor vehicle industry analysts in an article published earlier this month. I quote an article by John Mellor in the Bulletin of 7 May. In relation to Japanese, Australian and Korean built vehicles, he states:
After import duty, importer and dealer margins and sales tax are added, the Japanese car--
he is talking about something which is the equivalent of the Hyundai Stellar--
will sell for about $9,300.
The Australian car will retail for about $9,100 and the Korean car, after the 100 per cent duty has been levied, will retail for $5,900.

After looking at the situation in Canada, John Mellor is able to indicate the successful penetration of the Canadian market by Korean motor vehicles in a short period of time. Undoubtedly this is an issue which will have to commend itself to the Government for attention in the course of the refinement and fine tuning of any plans-such as the motor vehicle plan-which require a number of years to put in place and to see through to completion. It is undoubtedly true that one would have expected the introduction of a plan by the Government along these lines to have been welcomed by just about all sections of the industry. It disappoints me to a certain extent to see the attitude that is taken by Mr Thompson, New South Wales Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Federation of Australia, whom Senator Walsh was at pains to criticise during Question Time this afternoon. Immediately after the car plan was announced on 30 May 1984 Mr Thompson was quoted as saying that it:
. . . sounds the death knell for almost the whole of the component part industry.
It destroys the concept of having an Australian motor industry but its a major victory for GMH.
It is not as though Mr Thompson's opinion has changed very much in the period since 30 May 1984 because in a newspaper report of an address he gave on 6 May 1985 it is stated:

He continued his criticism of the plan to restructure the motor vehicle industry which he claimed would make it impossible for any Australian manufacturer to survive when the tariff on imported motor vehicles dropped to 57.5 per cent by 1992.

Clearly, one hopes that Minister Button's view of the development of the industry is correct and that Mr Thompson's view is not correct. However it is significant to note that this is not a plan which has necessarily been regarded as the saviour of the industry by everybody who is intimately connected with it.

I turn to the central point of this legislation which is the research funds which have been made available for the industry. I seek to elicit some response from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce or whoever is now present in the chamber to represent him in the debate this evening, on the way in which and the reasons for which certain changes have taken place between the time of the original announcement of this research program for the industry and the way in which we are now presented with the legislation in the Parliament. If one looks at the 'Information Kit on Motor Vehicle Policy' which was published by the Department of Industry and Commerce in May 1984, which sets out the details of the motor vehicle industry plan, one sees that the research component is clearly identified. Page 18 of the information kit, which in particular relates to design activities, states:
This assistance will operate through the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board, in consultation with the Automotive Industry Authority.

We know that between the announcement of the plan in May 1984 and the introduction of this legislation that something has changed. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), in his second reading speech, stated:
The Government also announced--
he is talking about an announcement last October--
that the Automotive Industry Authority would be responsible for the administration of the scheme.

The decision made between May 1984 and October 1984 to move the administration of this research plan from the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board to the Automotive Industry Authority has not been adequately or thoroughly explained by the Government. It is certainly not explained in the Minister's second reading speech and I do not think it has been explained in any of the comments which have been made on this legislation. On 20 October 1984, commenting on this change between the IRDIB scheme and the administration by the Automotive Industry Authority, Jane Ford-I do not need to remind honourable senators that Jane Ford is probably the most thoroughly informed and articulate writer on science policy in Australia-was prompted to write an article in the Australian as follows:

The Federal Government's plan to pour $150 million into new car industry research and design over the next five years underwent a major turnaround this week raising questions over the real purpose of the scheme.

No longer is it the responsibility of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board. Instead, it has been handed over to the new Automotive Industry Authority within the Department of Industry and Commerce and renamed the Motor Vehicles and Components Development Grant Scheme.

To many, the move, which involves unnecessary bureaucratic duplication of staff and resources and removes funding from the stringent scrutiny of the IRDIB, clearly shows that the scheme has much more to do with car industry politics than any real concern about research for the industry.
She went on:
Some see the funds as merely a disguise subsidy to the five major car companies to soften them up so that they go along with the Government's car rationalisation plan.

I do not believe that the Minister has sufficiently explained why it is that between May and October of last year this significant change took place in the way in which the research grants scheme is to be administered.

The Bill allows for research to be undertaken on questions of both design and style. Clause 5 (b) (iii) of the Bill before us states that an approved project may be one which involves 'design work that is primarily related to the style of an eligible product rather than to the functional characteristics of the product'. I am not altogether sure of the extent to which the expenditure of public money, alleged to be research expenditure, is properly comprehended by being spent on techniques of style change. This contributes nothing to fundamental engineering; it contributes nothing to fundamental research into safety or improved performance, economy or whatever it happens to be. Undoubtedly, there is a great deal of capacity within legislation so framed for money to be used for purposes which one would not think as proper expenditure of scarce research funds for matters of mere style. I suspect that that is one of the reasons for the change away from IRDIB with its strict criteria for grants, in favour of the scheme which is now put forward for the administration of this legislation. I worry about that to a certain extent and my fears on that matter are reinforced by a number of other comments. In the report of the Car Industry Council of 14 December 1983 the question of design was clearly addressed. The Council, in its report, stated:
The Council recognises that the downwards trend--
that is in technological progress and the retention of design skills--

results from the increasing costs associated with the development of new models, and that the relatively limited size of the Australian market would certainly not, other things being equal, encourage world manufacturers to maintain unique Australian design activities. Rather, Australian producers would increasingly purchase designs from overseas.

I think it has to be something slightly better than that as a justification for the expenditure of research money in that area. I am not heartened in this matter when I look once again at Senator Button's speech to the Trade Union Training Authority, which I quoted previously and in which he said, in relation to the report of the Car Industry Council:

The Government did not implement one of the recommendations of the Car Industry Council report which sought to place specific requirements on the vehicle manufacturers' expenditures on Australian sourced design and tooling.

I worry that not enough of this money will go to the important engineering and design aspects of local research which clearly need to be undertaken. I turn to the next area of concern about this expenditure; that is, the whole issue of computer usage and computer assistance in the manufacturing industry. We saw the publication in June 1984 of the so-called Cashman report entitled 'Establishment of an Advisory Service on Computer Assistance in the Manufacturing Industry'. The report had as a major recommendation, indeed, recommendation No. 1, that:
The Committee strongly recommends that there is an urgent need for the Government to establish a nationwide advisory service on computer assisted manufacturing.

That is something one would have thought was of enormous importance in the motor vehicle industry. Yet the Cashman report appears to have disappeared without comment or trace. The Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones, told us what a significant report it was going to be, in exactly the same way as he told us what a significant report the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development examiners report on science and technology in Australia was going to be. The Cashman report came down and, like the OECD report, the Government threw it in the waste paper basket. It is simply no good to continue this attitude towards the role of computer assistance in the manufacturing industry, particularly when we have before us major opportunities in terms of motor vehicles on which this impacts directly.

Lest it be thought that that is the only area of its kind, I draw the attention of the Senate to an excellent speech made by my colleague Senator Jessop in the Senate on 28 February this year on a matter of public importance. He dealt with the matter of the computer assisted disaster management scheme called CADMAS. He indicated that the scheme was refused funding under the provisions of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act, the Act to which I have referred previously, whose administrative and advisory body originally was to be charged with the responsibility of dealing with the $150m that was to be provided under this scheme. The point Senator Jessop made in his speech, and which I wish to make in the balance of my remarks this evening, is that with $150m available for research in the motor vehicle industry, one of the things that have happened at exactly the same time is that the rest of Australian science and technology is being absolutely starved of necessary assistance, absolutely starved of additional funding, and absolutely crippled by the attitude of this Government, which is fundamentally being exposed as being opposed to the development of excellence in the Australian research and scientific community.

Today in Question Time we saw the most extraordinary performance by Senator Button, wriggling on the hook, about whether the 150 per cent taxation deduction for contributions towards research was, in fact, going to take place. We were warned by the Australian Science and Technology Council in its report on computer-related technologies in the metal trades industry in January 1985 that a taxation incentive scheme ought to be introduced as a matter of urgency. Senator Button ran round the country promising largess all over the place. At the National Meeting of Concern on Science and Technology held in Canberra on 16 April this year, he said that one thing that was in the pipeline, that was projected for 1985-86, was that there would be a forgoing of revenue of $80m as a result of the 150 per cent taxation concession. He was not prepared to allow it to stand at that because on 2 May he told the Australian Academy of Science:
Similarly, a substantial amount of funding will go to the 150% tax concession for R &D which is intended to be the principal stimulant to research in the private sector.

We know that Mr Jones and his Department have always been opposed to this 150 per cent deduction. We read in the Australian of yesterday's date that a punch-up is occurring between Mr Keating and Senator Button as to whether this will be in place on 1 July 1985, or 1 July 1986, or indeed whether it will ever see the light of day. It is and has always been opposed by the Treasury. All Senator Button's wiggling and squirming in Question Time today leaves one with the impression only that this incentive so grandly promised in the Government's policy speech, out of thin air, having been opposed by Mr Jones's Department, is now once again up for grabs as part of the cost-cutting exercise, despite the fact that in April and May this year it was touted around to the Academy of Science and the National Meeting of Concern on Science and Technology by Senator Button as a centrepiece of the whole operation. Let me turn to just how miserly the Government has been in terms of its assistance to research in Australia in comparison with the money that it can find for this undertaking. Page 1425 of Hansard records that in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) in the House of Representatives, Mr MacKellar, the Opposition shadow Minister for Science, had this to say about the Australian research grants scheme:
In fact, as a result of that talking up--
that is, the talking up of science and technology by the Australian Labor Party and Mr Jones in particular--

a record number of applications, some 2,355, under the Australian research grants scheme were received for 1985. Significantly, there was a 40 per cent increase in applications from researchers in the fields of engineering and applied sciences. In all, requests were made for research funding amounting to $65.8m.
That is a pretty small amount compared with the $150m which is to be thrown around for all sorts of purposes in the motor vehicle industry. Mr MacKellar continued:

So when we look at the appropriation for 1984-85 we find that it met only 36 per cent of the demand-much less than half. In fact, only 26 per cent-just over a quarter-of the requests for new projects were accepted. That is the lowest proportion on record. This Government prides itself on its record in a number of areas. I do not think it would pride itself on the record of having granted the lowest proportion ever of requests for new projects.
Later he continued:

The figures bear some examination. Sixty per cent of Government support for industrial technology is not in the form of outlay on research and development but in the form of tax concessions, with the effect not being felt until 1987. The support for commercial outlay in high technology will remain frozen in money terms at the 1983-84 figure. The obligation to the car industry of $30m a year for five years, which is a political offset for the industry's acceptance of the car plan, has been introduced as a justification for freezing or cutting back the level of the national scientific effort. I remind the House and the people of Australia that the support for the car industry of $30m a year is greater than the total amount supporting the Australian research grants system.

The Government has a great deal of explaining to do, if it can possibly find any way of explaining away how the money can be so readily available for this largely political arrangement. The Opposition gives its support to anything that is prepared to provide at least some money for research and development in Australia. That is why we will give this Bill our full support. There is a great deal of explaining to be done as to why that sort of money can be found for a one-off industry arrangement to buy political peace in a particular industry at the cost of screwing down and, in fact, crippling the national research, development and scientific effort which is required in the rest of the country. Lest it be thought that this process is not an ongoing and continuing project, one can see in last weekend's National Times, the issue dated 3 to 9 May, an article by Robin Williams, one of the country's leading broadcasters and commentators on science, in which he said:
In this country science has suffered its greatest financial setback in modern times.

He was talking about this Government's science policy. One looks at the Australian of 1 May, just this month, and at the heading 'Our medical researchers get knocked back on extra cash'. Dr Blewett had a meeting with the leading medical researchers. The report says:

But Dr Blewett just looked at them glumly. Warnings about cuts in government spending have been well publicised. Apart from these, he explained that any extra money he had to play around with went towards resolving the doctors dispute.

Even in the area of medical research where we are world leaders there are cutbacks, restrictions and the crippling of the national effort. What is the result of this? Why, heavens above, Mr Jones leaps into the fray again and on 17 April writes to all university vice-chancellors pledging to continue to fight for more money for the Australian research grants scheme. On Mr Jones's track record they should not expect too much success when they come to this year's Budget.

There are two things on which the Government could have taken far more positive action, but about which it has done virtually nothing. In December 1984 the report of the Committee of Review on Offsets, the Inglis report, was published. It made major recommendations about what the Government ought to do about offsets arrangements. Yet in September 1984 we were being told that of $2,000m worth of offsets only $495m had so far been completed by local industry. The Government is simply not doing anything significant in this area. We have had two major reports from the Australian Science and Technology Council, one entitled 'Government Purchasing and Offsets Policies in Industrial Innovation', and the other entitled 'Computer-related Technologies in the Metal Trades Industry'. Both said that one of the most important things for the Government to do was to rid Australia of the ridiculous system of State preferences.

I know that Senator Button has been active in seeking to achieve this, and I give him full credit for having said on a number of occasions that he wants to end the system. Everybody has co-operated in getting rid of the system except New South Wales, which has as its Premier the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. For all the rhetoric we get from the Labor Party about offsets, nothing is done. For all the rhetoric we get from the Labor Party about State preferences purchasing arrangements and the difficulties they pose for Australian industrial development, any action is stymied by a government led by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party.

Finally, one can say in terms of science and technology that the assault upon the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation continues unabated. Mr Jones is engaged in a personal war against Dr Wild, the Chairman of CSIRO, and has a general view about CSIRO and what ought to be done to cripple it and bring it to heel and into accord with the ideological way in which he hopes to see these things developing. That statement is reinforced even today by a report in the Melbourne Age headed 'Review threat to CSIRO. Hawke, Jones clash over probe on Government funded studies'. We see once again that a war is going on between members of the Labor Party Government over the role of and financing to be provided for CSIRO. Once again, the long term sufferers will be the Australian economy, the Australian community and, in particular, the Australian scientific community.

This debate has allowed us simply to explore the extent to which this Government can find the money for specific industrial research and development and research and development in general when it feels minded to do so. It allows us to identify clearly that the test for the provision of money for research is no longer a test of national requirement or a test of excellence but a test of political requirement, favouritism and expediency. Members of the Opposition are not opposed to the scheme which this amending legislation seeks to put in place. We simply highlight the fact that the money is available to assist research in Australia. What is lacking is the political will on the part of the Government to employ that money in the sectors which will most benefit from it in Australia's long term interests. The shabby treatment given to science and technology in Australia by this Government is again highlighted in the demonstration that money is there but the political will is not behind it. Until the Government is prepared to come to grips with this, of all the records which it will put down in the history books the one which will stand out in the long term as the most significant is that this is the Government which did more to cripple Australia's scientific community and research effort than any other in this nation's history.

speech.speaker: Jessop Sen D.S.

talk.start.para: —I have listened with great interest to the speech made by Senator Puplick who has highlighted the deficiency of the Government in its regard for the need to finance research in industry and many other areas in Australia. In speaking on this Automotive Industry Authority Amendment Bill he highlighted the importance of research into automotive design. I sympathise with what he said and totally endorse the comments that he has made.
—That might be an error.

—I will come to the attitude of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce later. He is culpable in the area of research because he has ignored totally some areas of public interest grants that I believe he ought to have recognised as a matter of urgency. I will come to that later. What Senator Puplick said was highlighted by the fact that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) was not even given a guernsey at the National Economic Summit Conference. Representatives of all the people of Australia were supposed to have been called together to give the Government future direction on the economic progress of this country. Mr Jones, with due respect to some of the deficiencies that Senator Puplick adverted to, was unable to put a view in this important forum on the need to provide some stimulus to science and technology in Australia.

speech.para: At present the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment is conducting an inquiry into technological development and its possible effects on employment. Some public hearings have already been held. I am not frightened of technological development. Technological development-I am sure the Minister appreciates this because he has a knowing smile on his face-does not mean unemployment. In fact, if it is wisely approached in Australia it can mean employment opportunities for people requiring jobs. I think it is a very important question with which the Government should come to grips. We had a public hearing the other day in Canberra. A Professor Ford illustrated how tardy we are in Australia. He is a professor from New South Wales interested in human resources. He has been to Japan, West Germany, Sweden and Norway in pursuit of knowledge of industrial development in those countries. He has just returned from Japan where he examined the Toyota motor plant in company with a colleague of his from the United States of America.

To illustrate how far we are behind Japan, West Germany and other countries, for example, he told us at the public hearing that the company was going to change the run on the production line. I forget the exact detail. It may have been to change it from left-hand drive vehicles to right-hand drive vehicles. The company put a lot of thought into this. Professor Ford asked his United States counterpart how long that particular change in the production line would take in America. The American expert said that it would take about eight hours or one shift. Four workers were involved in this operation. Professor Ford put the stop watch on and five minutes and 44 seconds later that production line had been changed. If such a change takes eight hours in America, how long would it take in Australia? I imagine it would take two weeks or a month in view of the attitude of some of the trade unions in this country.

talk.start.para: —What are you talking about?

—The honourable senator from Western Australia, the import from the Scottish Isles, ought to know that one of the main reasons why Australia is lagging behind the rest of the world in respect of industrial development and technology simply is that there are too many trade unions in this country. Why are there too many trade unions in this country? There are too many trade unions because they have built up empires and bureaucracies within the trade union movement which they do not wish to relinquish. Restricting the number of unions is one of the success stories of places such as West Germany and Japan. I did not think I would be saying such things 10 or 15 years ago. I believe that having too many unions is one of the problems we have in Australia. The Toyota factory has to deal with only one trade union and it does so very effectively. When a change in technology is contemplated it consults with the trade union concerned and explains the problem. With the co-operation of the union, the factory then puts that action into effect. For example, last year in the Toyota factory no fewer than three million suggestions came from the employees on the factory floor as to how they could increase production. How many suggestions would come from the factory floor in Australia?
—One, sack you.

—Senator McIntosh said one suggestion. That would be about right. I think he is being unkind to the trade union movement in Australia because I believe there are some trade unionists in Australia who are genuinely interested in overcoming the problems that we face. I have listened to my friend from Western Australia talk about matters relating to the trade union movement over a long period. However, I believe that we have to come to grips with the problems if Australian technology is to be introduced for the benefit of Australians and with the purpose of providing jobs in Australia at present.

speech.para: It is quite evident to me that the example of Japan and its system of technological development is one we could profit by in Australia. Motor vehicle production in Japan is in the order of 11 million units a year. If we look back a few years to when Japan was pressured by competition from South Korea, Taiwan and other low wage structured countries we see that Japan made decisions to change its technology. It decided to computerise production lines. That meant a reduction in the factory floor staff of 50 per cent. In respect of the motor car industry, the factories concerned consulted with the one trade union associated with that industry. The factories pointed out the need for this technological change and showed that there was a need to reduce the factory floor staff by 50 per cent. They then carefully made the point that it would not be a question of retrenchment. It was a matter of going about the problem in a rational way and explaining to the workers on the factory floor who would no longer be needed in that part of the industry that they would be retrained and fitted into other parts of the industry that would expand because of the particular technological development. That is exactly what happened. The process took three years. During that time people were retrained and their productivity increased by 30 per cent. The factories increased employment by 3 per cent. I think that is a lesson that Australia can learn.

The Minister gave one of his knowing, but I hope sympathetic, smiles when I started my speech. I know he is genuinely interested in industrial development in Australia. I pay him that dubious compliment. I believe he recognises that for years under successive governments industry in Australia has been propped up by tariff protection which, in my view, has meant that in Australia we have lost that entrepreneurial drive and spirit. This is simply because successive governments have chosen the easy way out and provided tariff protection rather than an equivalent amount of money to provide incentives for industry in Australia to become innovative, entrepreneurial and more effective and efficient as far as the world scene is concerned. Senator Puplick kindly referred to a speech which I made in respect of the computer assisted disaster management project, CADMAS, which is devised to deal with natural disaster situations, such as the Ash Wednesday bushfires, floods and so on. I notice that in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill it is stated:

Clause 9 introduces a new section 27A, similar to Section 39 of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976, which empowers the Authority, subject to Ministerial directions, to make arrangements for the carrying out of public interest projects.

At a recent Estimates committee meeting I asked why CADMAS was not funded under the public interest grant section of the Act. The departmental officers said that it was because CADMAS did not comply. I believe that the department concerned attempted to answer the question. However, I ask: What could be of more public interest than a centralised computer system dealing with natural disasters, such as the Ash Wednesday bushfires? I think the Minister has been culpable in this matter because it is clearly within his power to say to those bureaucrats: 'CADMAS is in the public interest and ought to be funded'. However, because of his indecision and, I suggest, his incompetence, this project has been delayed for around two or three years. Of course, what will happen is that the company involved in the development of this very important public interest project will have to derive financial assistance from the United States of America. Already a company has provided in the order of $2m for this project. Unless the Government recognises the need to give these sorts of projects some support, that company will move to the United States of America, to the detriment of industrial development in this country. I could go on for a long period reminding the Minister of such situations. He still has that knowing smirk on his face and is still chewing the end of his spectacles, contemplating what we will say and how he will reply to my charges of total negligence and lack of interest with respect to matters of public interest.

talk.start.para: —I would wait and see, if I were you, how I am going to reply.

—I hope that the Minister will respond. I really believe that the Minister does have some smattering of interest in developing technology in this country. I do believe-he is scratching his head, again thinking about what he will say-that he will respond positively to my charge that he has been negligent. I hope he will say that he has made a decision about the question of a public interest grant to this company. I could mention innumerable cases in relation to negligence on the part of previous governments. I accuse the previous Government of which I was a member of the same negligence. I think Australians are rather complacent about what was our comfortable situation until the present Government took office. Now we are not feeling very comfortable. I talked to some people today who are contemplating a visit to London and it will cost them dearly because of the Australian dollar's abysmal rate of exchange. Clearly, one of the matters that probably contribute to that exchange rate is the subject we are discussing at present-the neglect of technological research support in Australia.

speech.para: Another project that comes to mind is an oxygen probe that was developed in South Australia at the Flinders University. This particular probe would enable, for example, the aluminium industry to save about 20 per cent or 30 per cent in electricity charges because of the injection of oxygen into the furnaces required in that industry. We have failed to come to grips with that particular technology. I am glad that the Minister wisely nods, because unless he takes some action in this area that particular technology will go overseas. Australians are very good at initial research, but regrettably we are very slow to provide the government incentive to develop those initiatives. Quite frequently we find that the initiatives are taken up by overseas companies and the export income that could be derived from those initiatives is lost to Australia. Surely the Minister, who now has a slightly different look on his face because he is obviously interested in this area, must be concerned about the disastrous situation in which we find ourselves in Australia at present. We noted when the last Budget was brought down that $5.9 billion of taxpayers' money was being spent in servicing public loans. Therefore, what we are talking about tonight is not necessarily totally applicable to the motor car industry. It also applies to other industries in Australia which desperately need the encouragement of the Minister and his sympathy with respect to public interest grants.

I suggest that the Minister may have been snowed by his Department in relation to the matters to which I have referred. I have some faith in the Minister's interest in technological progress in Australia and the need to stimulate and encourage Australian industry to take not only the necessary developmental steps but also the entrepreneurial drive that is needed to sell our products on the international market. I know that the Minister wants me to wind up.

talk.start.para: —I suggested a new gesture to be included in Hansard.

—The Minister is encouraging me to give the Government a little more of the medicine that it needs. When we consider the Japanese example, the West German example, which is not quite as efficient as the Japanese example, the Swedish example and the Norwegian example of technology encouragement, I think Australia can learn a lot and profit from the lessons that have been learned or the examples of the effective management overseas. Too often Australia follows blindly and copies the mistakes that have been made overseas. I think that the matter we are dealing with tonight and the encouragement that flows from the suggestions that have come from this side of the chamber, give the Minister the opportunity to do something about the encouragement of technological development by providing public interest grants, research grants, that will create jobs for Australians and export markets for Australia. In doing so, I believe that the Government will profit in the long term by reducing our disastrous balance of payments situation and doing something to reduce the interest that we in Australia are paying on public borrowings.

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —I thank those honourable senators who have made thoughtful contributions to the debate on the Automotive Industry Authority Amendment Bill 1985 which is before the Senate. I exclude Senator Puplick and Senator Jessop from the category. In the course of their remarks they provoked me to say something about some of the issues that they raised. I do not mind being described as incompetent by Senator Jessop along with a variety of other adjectives which he used to describe me. I am quite used to that. In a way, I object to being described as culpable, and I want to tell him why. The first point I make to Senator Jessop is that he keeps asking the rhetorical question: Why have these miracles which happened in Japan, West Germany, Sweden and Norway, not happened in Australia? One of the reasons why they have not happened in Australia is that in countries like Sweden, as I pointed out to the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, in the debate a few days ago-
—Here we go; a cracked gramophone record.

—A cracked record, but I will play it again. If the honourable senator does not like it, that is bad luck. One of the reasons why a lot of these things have not happened is that we have had 30 years of Liberal Government in the last 35 years, and in Sweden--
—The way we are going, we will have another 30 coming up.
—It would be disastrous for the country if the next 30 years were anything like the last 30 years, if a Liberal government were elected again-
—You cannot have a sensible debate on anything. You are incapable of sensible debate on any subject.

—The honourable senator should stop behaving like the prefect manque again. I am dealing with Senator Jessop, not him. I will come to his contribution in a minute. That is one of the reasons why these things have not happened in Australia. Senator Jessop conjured up all sorts of expressions, such as 'entrepreneurial skills'. He said: 'Why has not the Government done something about entrepreneurial skills?' I invite Senator Jessop to make an intelligent speech in this Parliament-if he is capable of doing so-about what any government can do in regard to entrepreneurial skills. (Quorum formed) Mr Acting Deputy President, I point out that the quorum was called because I was inviting Senator Jessop to make an intelligent speech in the Senate. The pain of that thought was altogether too much for him and he declined to listen to that suggestion. Senator Jessop ranged over a wide number of countries and asked why things that were done in those countries could not be done here. There are a number of reasons for this. I would just make a point in respect of the motor vehicle industry that we are discussing. Quite favourable comparisons can be made between our motor car industry and overseas motor car industries. For example, it takes about the same time to assemble a car in Australia as it does to assemble the same car in West Germany. It takes something like 22 hours to assemble a car in those two countries which can be assembled in 10 hours in Japan and 43 hours in the United Kingdom. So there are comparisons which are valid and favourable to this industry in the international context. These are comparisons which I thought Senator Jessop might have made if he had wanted to talk about the car industry at all, which he clearly did not want to do. However, the thrust of Senator Jessop's speech was, of course, directed to CADMAS and other projects which have been considered by the Australian Industries Research and Development Incentives Advisory Council and the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board. An oxygen probe for the aluminium industry would save that industry 20 per cent in fuel costs.
—And the motor industry.

—And the motor industry. It was in this area that I was described as culpable because I had not directed bureaucrats to say that the CADMAS scheme should be funded. Of course, I point out to Senator Jessop that it was the thrust of previous governments in setting up the AIRDIB scheme generally that these decisions should be made at arm's length from government. It is a policy with which I generally agree that decisions about research funding should be made at arm's length from government. One of the important points about that proposition is simply that people such as Senator Jessop and me should not be able to interfere with those decisions and should not be seen to interfere with those decisions.
—Tell that to Mr Jones and the CSIRO.

—I think that is a quite proper principle. Senator Puplick's interjection is quite irrelevant and silly in the context of what I am talking about. Decisions in regard to granting money to companies should be made at arms length from government. That is the important point in the whole AIRDIB scheme. It is to stop people like Senator Jessop and me picking out our favourite scientist or our favourite inventions and seeing that they are funded by government. There should be an independent assessment. That is the function of the scheme. The CADMAS scheme to which the honourable senator referred was dealt with by both AIRDIAC and AIRDIB. In both cases they said that the development of this project should be taken up by the private sector.

speech.para: All I can say in regard to the second matter to which Senator Jessop referred is that I do not know whether that has been the subject of an application for a grant by AIRDIB, but if the aluminium industry in Australia which, after all, is not exactly broke, thought that it could save 20 per cent of its fuel costs, I think it might be interested in shelling out a couple of hundred thousand dollars for that development to be progressed. Apparently it is not. I would have thought that that is what the honourable senator was talking about in terms of entrepreneurial skills and awareness. If that invention or whatever it is had that benefit, I am sure the industry would have taken it up. So I do not regard what Senator Jessop has had to say as right. I believe that his views quite clearly stem from a misunderstanding of the AIRDIB scheme and the work of AIRDIAC. I think the honourable senator ought to go back and have a look at the legislation because if he does he will understand it better.

The honourable member also gave us a little lecture about the virtues of Toyota in Japan. I, like Senator Jessop, have been around the Toyota assembly line and have had the benefit of being told about the number of suggestions that that company gets from members of the work force and so on every year. I do not regard that as a helpful contribution to the debate. However, it might help Senator Jessop, if he wanted a better understanding of the Japanese car industry, to read a book called Japan in the Passing Lane which is about the Toyota Corporation's operations in Japan. He could then tell us something about the applicability of Japanese organisational structures and working conditions to the Australian industry scene. I think he would then realise that they are not easily translatable into Australia as most other countries, including the United States of America, have recognised for a long time.
Some other contributions were made to the debate by Senators Foreman and Jack Evans to which I do not wish to refer in detail because they were positive.

talk.start.para: —Senator Jack Evans did not speak, so that shows the close attention you have paid.

—I am sorry. I did not mean by way of speech. My recollection is that Senator Evans interjected earlier in the debate. I thought it was a thoughtful interjection and a better contribution to the debate than any of the speeches made by honourable senators opposite.

speech.para: I wanted to refer also to the remarks made by Senator Puplick which I think are largely misconceived in the context of the present debate. It was one of those well rehearsed speeches, before a mirror I suspect, which dealt with a number of issues relating to research and development and--

talk.start.para: —You are an objectionable man, objectionable and pompous.
—I have taken a note of that. I will put that in my black book.
—That is typical, too.
—I suppose the honourable senator means that it is offensive to him.
—Why don't you deal with the points instead of being abusive?
—I am dealing with points which were made by other honourable senators when the honourable senator was not in the chamber.
—I was in the chamber.

—Perhaps the honourable senator's interjections will have more validity when I deal with him. A number of questions were raised. Senator Puplick referred to a number of areas of what he regards as Government inaction. He referred to the Inglis report on offsets. He made the point that a large area of offset entitlement or opportunity was not being taken up by Australian companies. I do not wish to digress to refer him to the particular passages of the Inglis report which deal with this issue. They do make the point, however, that the estimates of opportunities not taken up were vastly overstated. It is not that they are not being dealt with but, of course, there are a number of companies which, for reasons of quality or price that are not the subject of this debate, cannot match the requirements of the principal contractors.

speech.para: Senator Puplick asked why the motor vehicle scheme was not dealt with by AIRDIB under the AIRDIAC scheme as was originally considered. I make it quite clear that that possibility was considered in great detail and at some length. However, I think it is quite clear to most people that the design and research incentives provided under this legislation are part of a total package directed towards the promotion of the restructuring and reorientation of the motor vehicle industry. In the Government's view it is appropriate that judgments on this matter cannot be made on general criteria but have to take into account what is actually happening in the industry and how the project would relate to the activities of other firms in the industry and the process of restructuring. It was our view, finally, that the Authority would be in the best position to make such judgments because it is in day to day contact with the industry and has a detailed knowledge of developments in the industry and their implications for Government policy. Senator Puplick also made some good rhetorical points about the general levels of funding of research and development, the directions of research and development funding, and so on. I do not propose to deal in detail with those matters in the course of this debate. I suspect that we will have plenty of opportunity to debate those issues at some future time. They are not strictly relevant to the subject matter of this Bill.

I thank Senator Chaney for his general support of the legislation before the Senate. By implication, or even directly, he asked a number of questions about the future of the industry. Some of those questions are susceptible to answers, others cannot be answered because this industry, as an international industry, is in a sense a movable feast. Many of the projections for the future have to be considered in that context. Senator Chaney asked whether the plan was negotiable in the future. From the day of announcement of the plan my answer has been no, that the broad parameters of the plan are not negotiable. As I have said, on recommendations from the Authority, if necessary the Government will make adjustments to minor aspects of the plan, but that is all.

Senator Chaney also asked about the future of the industry in the light of the development of a motor vehicle industry in Korea. That is a question that has to be asked in every country of the world. It is quite extraordinary that it was not being asked in Australia a year ago. I find it very strange that the industry was not addressing the problem of the development of the Korean motor industry. Obviously the fixation with the Japanese industry was too strong. If I were to hazard a guess about the Korean motor vehicle industry, I think it will be very competitive in international terms. I suspect that the Japanese industry may become marginally less competitive in world terms than it has been in recent years. All sorts of changes will occur in the competitive relationships of various motor vehicle industries around the world. One result of that undoubtedly will be that throughout the world there will be considerable moves towards more joint ventures between motor manufacturing companies, as is already happening an Italy and the United States, and we believe and hope will happen in Australia, for the benefit of the industry as a whole. It is impossible to say at this stage what the level of competitiveness and the impact of the Korean motor industry on the Australian market is likely to be in 1989 or 1990, for example. The fact remains that, whatever its level of competitiveness, it will be considerable. The Australian industry has to make enormous adjustments to meet that degree of competitiveness, and that is essentially what the motor vehicle plan is about.

When Senator Chaney asks whether any of the plan's parameters are under threat, in a sense my answer is yes, in a number of respects, because it depends on the degree of technological development in this industry as against other industries and it depends on the general level of economic activity in Australia. Senator Chaney made the obvious point that the industry has had an enormously successful 18 months. The projections for the immediate future are very bullish. When the plan was being developed we made a number of assumptions about the future of the plan on the basis that there would be a 2 per cent increase per year in the passenger motor vehicle market in Australia over the seven years of the plan. In the last 1 1/2 years there has been a growth rate of 10 per cent or more in each of those years. That illustrates that assumptions of this kind-assumptions which I think were very conservative, and properly conservative-can be considerably astray. Of course, as Senator Chaney properly points out that affects the response to the plan and the level of enthusiasm for it.

Senator Chaney asked-I may not have the form of the question quite right-whether the Government will take a more directive approach to this industry further down the track. The answer is that right from the beginning the Government has taken the position that it reserves the right to take a more directive approach if in the light of advice from the Automotive Industry Authority it decides that the objectives of the plan are not being met. We have no wish or intention to do that. This is precisely why the Automotive Industry Authority, contrary to a lot of advice the Government was given, was established as a body without teeth, in a sense. The Automotive Industry Authority was established as a body that was to exert a persuasive role on the industry and a negotiating role in a whole range of matters rather than being an interventionist body which would tell companies what to do. We wish to avoid that if we possibly can. If the survival of a motor vehicle industry in this country is dependent on a more interventionist approach in some matters, particularly in relation to the behaviour of importers and the behaviour of companies in terms of their capacity to co-operate with each other and in terms of the various component sectors co-operating with the manufacturers, then if those things are absent the answer is that the Government may have to be slightly more directive than it has been in the past.

The question of shutting out new entrants was also raised. In the Government's view there is no reason for new entrants to be cut out of this market. I say that particularly in relation to component manufacturers. In fact, in the last 12 months a number of restructuring moves have taken place within the component manufacturing industry which have resulted in new entrants into the market. New entrants, who brought with them better technology and perhaps better management, have been encouraged by the Government. Certainly that will be so throughout the life of the plan as far as this Government is concerned. At this stage I would shudder to think of a new entrant to the plan manufacturers. I would need to be persuaded that that was in any sense in the best interests of this country or of the industry as a whole. I take it that the question was basically directed to the component sector.

Those are the major questions Senator Chaney addressed in his speech.
